headline: Georgia gubernatorial race: Kemp leads Trump-backed Perdue in AJC poll
author: Ronn Blitzer
sentences: The Atlanta Journal-Constitution poll, which was administered by the University of Georgia's School of Public and International Affairs Survey Research Center, showed that 53.3% of likely GOP primary voters in the state planned to vote for Kemp.

STACEY ABRAMS TRAILS BRIAN KEMP, DAVID PERDUE FOR GEORGIA GOVERNOR, NEW POLL SHOWS
The poll also addressed other races in the state, including Senate and Georgia secretary of state.
Perdue and Hice are both backed by Trump, but while neither appears to be in a comfortable position in their respective races, that does not seem to reflect on Trump himself.
A total of 70.8% had a favorable view of the incumbent governor, with 20.9% unfavorable, while 56.6% had a favorable view of Perdue and 30.2% said unfavorable.
Brian Kemp with a substantial lead over former Sen. David Perdue roughly a month before their May 24 Republican primary contest.
For Senate, 65.9% chose Herschel Walker, with the second-highest going to Gary Black with just 6.7%, as 22.9% were undecided.
Participants were also split on Raffensperger, who drew the ire of former President Donald Trump after the 2020 election.
According to the poll, 77.4% have a favorable view of the ex-president, with 14.6% unfavorable and 7.9% unsure.
Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger's primary race against Rep. Jodi Hice appears to be much closer.
Just 34.3% viewed him favorably, compared to 35.6% unfavorable and 30.1% saying they did not know.
Walker had a favorability rating of 76.8% with just 9.6% saying they had an unfavorable view.
For Hice, it was 37.2% favorable, 8.9% unfavorable, and 53.9% said they did not know.
Among the rest of the participants, which were 886 in total, 15.4% were undecided.
Kemp also fared much better than Perdue when it came to favorability.
Of the remainder, most were for Kandiss Taylor, who had 3.6%.
The incumbent had just 28.1% compared to 26.4% for Hice.
A new poll shows Georgia Gov.
